awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2019 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Ethan Levien is "Understanding the effects of variability at the single cell level on microbial population growth." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Ariel Amir.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
During this award, the PI and collaborators sought to understand the role of non-genetic variability in microbial population dynamics. Non-genetic variation, such as variation in growth rates between genetically identical cells, is known to play an important role in cancer and bacterial infections. Yet, there are key gaps in our understanding of how variability at the single-cell level propagates to the population level. This NSF postdoc was supervised by Ariel Amir in the School of Engineering and Applied Mathematics at Harvard.

The outcomes of this research were the following:

  • The interplay of phenotypic variability and fitness in finite microbial populations E. Levien, J. Kondev, A. Amir Journal of the Royal Society Interface 17 (166), 20190827

In this article, the PI and collaborators explored the relationship between different methods for sampling lineages from a finite population in which division times are heritable. This helps us better understand data from certain microfluidic experiments where small populations of cells are observed under a microscope.

  • Large Deviation Principle Linking Lineage Statistics to Fitness in Microbial Populations E. Levien, T. GrandPre, A. Amir Physical Review Letters 125, 048102

In this article, the PI and collaborators developed an algorithm for predicting the growth rates of a population based on measurements of single lineages of cells.

  • The interplay of phenotypic variability and fitness in finite microbial populations E. Levien, J. Kondev, A. Amir Journal of the Royal Society Interface 17 (166), 20190827

This is a review paper that provides a widely accessible and unified treatment of many mathematical models of populations with non-genetic variability. The authors also present some new results that reveal the subtle ways model details can shape whether variability is beneficial or deleterious.

  • Time-resolved microfluidics unravels individual cellular fates during double-strand break repair N. Vertti-Quintero, E. Levien, L. Poggi, A. Amir, G.F. Richard, C.N. Baroud BMC Biology 20 (1), 269

In this paper, with experimental collaborators, we studied how randomness in the breaking and repair of DNA shapes population-level variability.

In addition to the research mentioned above, the PI engaged in mentorship, teaching, and outreach. These activities include the following:

  • Mentoring 2 REU students at Harvard.
  • Teaching a research course at the Marine Biology Lab at Woods Hole.
  • Volunteering to help students write graduate application essays through the Women+ of Color Project (https://thewocproject.org/).
  • TAing a course on quantitative biology at Brandeis under the direction of Jane Kondev.
  • Teaching AM105 (Differential Equations) at Harvard in the spring of 2021.

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2023
Modified by: Ethan A Levien
